name: Anne Condon
knownFor: Fellow of the Royal Society of Canada

anecdotes.title: Education
anecdotes.body: Anne received her BSc in 1982 (UCC, Ireland), and her Ph.D. in 1987 (Washington). Her research interests are in biomolecular computation and computational prediction of RNA and DNA structure and folding pathways, with applications to the design of novel structures and gene synthesis.

anecdotes.title: Contribution
anecdotes.body: She served on the Computing Research Association board from 1994-2007 and was Co-Chair from 2000-2003. She led the Distributed Mentor Project (now known as DREU) from 1996-1999. Anne has also served as ACMâ€™s Canadian Ambassador. She held the NSERC/General Motors Canada Chair for Women in Science and Engineering (2004-2009).

anecdotes.title: Awards
anecdotes.body: In 2010, she won the A. Nico Habermann Award for 'long-standing and impactful service toward the goal of increasing the participation of women in computer science research'. In 2012, she won the Engineering Diamond Award for Distinguished Achievement in Academia from the University of Washington. In 2014, she was the winner of the Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing Technical Leadership ABIE Award.

anecdotes.title: University of British Columbia
anecdotes.body: She is the head of the faculty of computer science at the University of British Columbia, researching theoretical computer science, and working on several other programming and mathematical projects.
